R, r

re-
pref (used widely with vs and related ns, adjs and advs ¿É×÷Ğí¶à¶¯´Ê¼°ÓÉ¶¯´ÊÅÉÉúµÄÃû´Ê¡¢ ĞÎÈİ´ÊºÍ¸±´ÊµÄÇ°×º) again ÔÙ; ÓÖ; ÖØĞÂ: reapply * redecoration * re-entered * reassuringly.
re-
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨: In many verbs beginning with re- the prefix is pronounced / rI-; rI-/ or / re-; rZ-/ and it may have lost its original meaning of `again' or `back' ÔÚÒÔ re- ¿ªÊ¼µÄĞí¶à¶¯´ÊÖĞ, Õâ¸öÇ°×º¶Á×÷ / rI-; rI-/ »ò / re-; rZ-/, ²¢ÓĞ¿ÉÄÜÒÑÊ§È¥Ô­À´µÄ£àÔÙ¡¢ ÓÖ£§»ò£à»Ø£§µÈÒâÒå: / rI-; rI-/ recall, repair; / re-; rZ-/ represent. Other verbs have had re- added to them with the meaning of `again' and it is pronounced / ri:-; ri-/ ÁíÓĞÒ»Ğ©¶¯´Ê¼Ó re- ±íÊ¾£àÔÙ¡¢ ÓÖ£§Ö®Òâ, ¶Á×÷ /ri:-; ri/: reopen; recreate. There are a few verbs which fit into both groups and a hyphenmay be used to show the distinction »¹ÓĞÒ»Ğ©¶¯´ÊÊÊºÏì¶ÉÏÊöÁ½ÖÖÇé¿ö, ¿ÉÓÃÁ¬½ÓºÅ±íÊ¾ÕâÖÖÇø±ğ: recount / rI5kaUnt; rI`kaJnt/ = `tell a story', re-count / 9ri:5kaUnt;9ri`kaJnt/ = `count again'; recover / rI5kQvE(r); rI`kQvL/ = `get back' or `become well again', re-cover / 9ri:5kQvE(r);9ri`kQvL/ = `supply with a new cover'.

reach 
n  1 [sing] extent to which a hand, etc can be stretched out ÉìÊÖµÈ¿É´ïµ½µÄ¾àÀë: a boxer with a long reach ³öÈ­¾àÀëÔ¶µÄÈ­»÷ÊÖ.  2 [C usu pl Í¨³£×÷¸´Êı] continuous extent of a river between two bends or of a canal between two locks £¨ºÓÁ÷Á½ÍäÇú´¦»òÔËºÓÁ½´¬Õ¢Ö®¼äµÄ£©ºÓ¶Î: the upper/lower reaches of the Thames Ì©ÎîÊ¿ºÓµÄÉÏ[ÏÂ]ÓÎ.  3 (idm Ï°Óï) beyond/out of/within (one's) `reach (a) outside or inside the distance that a hand, etc can be stretched out ÊÖ²»ÄÜ¼°[ÉìÊÖ¿É¼°]: have a dictionary within (arm's) reach °Ñ´Êµä·ÅÔÚ£¨ÉìÊÖ£©¹»µÃÖøµÄµØ·½ * The shelf is so high it is well out of/beyond my reach. ¼Ü×ÓÌ«¸ß, ÎÒ¸ù±¾¹»²»Öø. * Keep those medicines out of reach of the children/out of the children's reach. °ÑÄÇĞ©Ò©·ÅÔÚº¢×Ó¹»²»ÖøµÄµØ·½. reaction
/ rI5AkFn; rI`AkFEn/ n  1 [C, U] ~ (to sb/sth) response to a situation, an act, an influence, etc £¨¶ÔÇé¿ö¡¢ ĞĞ¶¯¡¢ Ó°ÏìµÈ×ö³öµÄ£©·´Ó¦, »ØÓ¦: What was his reaction to the news? / 5rIElIzEm; `rIEl9IzEm/ n [U]  1 attitudes and behaviour based on the acceptance of facts and the rejection of sentiment and illusion ÏÖÊµÖ÷ÒåµÄÌ¬¶ÈºÍĞĞÎª.  2 (in art and literature) portrayal of familiar things as they really are without idealizing them £¨ÎÄÒÕµÄ£©ÏÖÊµÖ÷Òå, Ğ´ÊµÖ÷Òå. reason
/ 5ri:zn; `rizn/ n  1 [C, U] ~ (for sth/doing sth); ~ (to do sth); ~ (why.../that...) reason
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨: A cause (of something) is what makes something happen *causeÖ¸ÊÂÎï·¢ÉúµÄÔ­Òò: The police are investigating the cause of the explosion. ¾¯·½ÕıÔÚµ÷²é±¬Õ¨µÄÔ­Òò. *  The causes of the First World War. µÚÒ»´ÎÊÀ½ç´óÕ½µÄÆğÒò. Reason (for something) has a wider use. *reasonÒ»´ÊÓÃ·¨½Ï¹ã. It can be the explanation that people give for why something is done ¿ÉÓÃÒÔ½âÊÍ×öÄ³ÊÂµÄÔ­Òò»òÀíÓÉ: What was the reason for his resignation? ? *  She didn't give any reasons for leaving. ËıÎ´×öÈÎºÎ½âÊÍ¾Í×ßÁË. Reason, justification and cause (for something) can indicate that the explanation is acceptable to people in general, or reasonable *reason¡¢ justification¡¢ causeÈı´Ê¾ùÖ¸ÓÃÒÔ½âÊÍµÄÀíÓÉÊÇÒ»°ãÈË¶¼¿ÉÒÔ½ÓÊÜµÄ, »òÔ»reasonable: The police had no reason to suspect him/no justification for suspecting him/no cause for suspicion (ie They didn't suspect him or shouldn't have suspected him). ¾¯·½ÊÇÃ»ÓĞÀíÓÉ»³ÒÉËûµÄ£¨¼´: ¾¯·½Î´»³ÒÉËû»ò²»¸Ã»³ÒÉËû£©. ÿ?BGround is the formal, especially legal, justification for an action. *groundÊÇÓÃì¶½Ï×¯ÖØ³¡ºÏµÄÁíÒ»Í¬Òå´Ê, ÓÈÓÃì¶·¨ÂÉÎÄ¼şÖĞ. It is commonly used in the plural ´Ë´Ê³£ÓÃ×÷¸´Êı: Boredom is not a ground for divorce. ÈÕ¾ÃÉúÑá²»ÄÜ³ÉÎªÀë»éµÄÀíÓÉ. *  I left my job on medical grounds. ÎÒÓÉì¶½¡¿µÔ­Òò¶ø´ÇÈ¥ÁË¹¤×÷. A motive for doing something is a feeling or desire within people which makes them act *motiveÖ¸Ïë×öÄ³ÊÂµÄ¸Ğ¾õ»òÔ¸Íû: He claimed that his motive for stealing was hunger. ËûËµËûÒòÎª¶ö²ÅÈ¥Íµ¶«Î÷. *  The crime seemed to have been committed without (a) motive. ÕâÒ»×ï°¸ËÆºõ²¢ÎŞ×÷°¸¶¯»ú.
reason
/ 5ri:zn; `rizn/ v  1 (a) [I] use one's power to think, understand, form opinions, etc Ë¼¿¼; Àí½â; ÍÆÀí: man's ability to reason ÈËµÄË¼¿¼ÄÜÁ¦. recent
/ 5ri:snt; `risnt/ adj [usu attrib Í¨³£×÷¶¨Óï] (that existed, happened, began, was/were made, etc) not long ago or before ²»¾ÃÇ°µÄ; ½üÀ´µÄ: a recent event, development, occurrence, etc ²»¾ÃÇ°µÄÊÂ¼ş¡¢ ·¢Õ¹¡¢ ÊÂÇéµÈ * In recent years there have been many changes. ×î½ü¼¸ÄêÓĞÁËĞí¶à±ä»¯. * Ours is a recent acquaintance, ie We only met a short time ago. ÎÒÃÇÊÇ×î½ü²ÅÈÏÊ¶µÄ. =>Usage at new ÓÃ·¨¼ûnew.
recently 
adv not long ago or before; lately ²»¾ÃÇ°; ½üÀ´: until quite recently Ö±µ½²»¾ÃÒÔÇ° * a recently painted house ×î½ü·ÛË¢¹ıµÄ·¿×Ó.
recently
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨: Recently, not long ago, lately indicate that the action spoken about took place in the recent past. *recently¡¢ not long ago¡¢ lately¾ùÖ¸×î½ü·¢Éú¹ıµÄÊÂ.  1 Recently has the widest use, in positive and negative statements and questions, with the past tense and the present perfect tense *recentlyÓÃ·¨×î¹ã, ¿ÉÓÃì¶¿Ï¶¨Ê½³ÂÊö¾ä¡¢ ·ñ¶¨Ê½³ÂÊö¾ä¼°ÒÉÎÊ¾äÖĞ, Óë¹ıÈ¥Ê±Ì¬ºÍÏÖÔÚÍê³ÉÊ±Ì¬Á¬ÓÃ: Did she have a party recently? Ëı×î½ü¾Ù°ì¹ı¾Û»áÂğ? *  They've recently bought a new car. ËûÃÇ²»¾ÃÇ°ÂòÁËÒ»Á¾ĞÂÆû³µ.  2 Not long ago is only used in positive statements with the verb in the past tense *not long ago½öÓÃì¶¿Ï¶¨Ê½³ÂÊö¾äÖĞ, Óë¶¯´Ê¹ıÈ¥Ê±Ì¬Á¬ÓÃ: They arrived in Britain not long ago/recently. ËûÃÇ²»¾ÃÒÔÇ°[×î½ü]µ½´ïÓ¢¹ú. *  It's not long ago that they arrived in Britain. ËûÃÇÊÇ²»¾ÃÒÔÇ°µ½´ïÓ¢¹úµÄ.  3 Lately is used in questions and negative statements. *latelyÓÃì¶ÒÉÎÊ¾äºÍ·ñ¶¨Ê½³ÂÊö¾äÖĞ. In positive statements it is used generally with only, much and a lot. ÈôÓÃì¶¿Ï¶¨Ê½³ÂÊö¾äÖĞ, Í¨³£Óëonly¡¢ much¡¢ a lotÁ¬ÓÃ. The verb must be in the present perfect tense¶¯´Ê±ØĞëÓÃÏÖÔÚÍê³ÉÊ±Ì¬: Have you seen him lately/recently? Äã½üÀ´[×î½ü]¼û¹ıËûÂğ? *  They haven't written lately/recently. ËûÃÇ½üÀ´[×î½ü]Ã»ÓĞĞ´ĞÅ. *  She's only lately/recently begun working here. ËıÖ»ÊÇ½üÀ´[×î½ü]²Å¿ªÊ¼ÔÚÕâÀï¹¤×÷µÄ. *  I've seen a lot of her lately/recently. ÎÒ½üÀ´[×î½ü]³£¼ûµ½Ëı.

reckon
/ 5rekEn; `rZkEn/ v  1 [Tn.pr, Tf, Cn.a esp passive ÓÈÓÃì¶±»¶¯ÓïÌ¬, Cn.n esp passive ÓÈÓÃì¶±»¶¯ÓïÌ¬, Cn.n/a esp passive ÓÈÓÃì¶±»¶¯ÓïÌ¬, Cn.t esp passive ÓÈÓÃì¶±»¶¯ÓïÌ¬] ~ sb/sth among sth; ~ sb/sth as sth (infml ¿Ú) (not used in the continuous tenses ²»ÓÃì¶½øĞĞÊ±Ì¬) be of the opinion or consider that sb/sth is as specified ÈÏÎªÄ³ÈË[Ä³ÊÂÎï]ÊÇ...: We reckon her among our best reporters. ÎÒÃÇÈÏÎªËıÊÇÎÒÃÇ×îºÃµÄ¼ÇÕß. * I reckon (that) he is too old for the job. ÎÒÈÏÎªËûÄêÁäÌ«´ó, ²»ÊÊì¶×öÕâ¹¤×÷. * The price was reckoned high. ¼ÛÇ®Î´ÃâÌ«¸ßÁË. * She is reckoned (to be) the cleverest pupil in the class. ËıÊÇ°àÉÏ×î´ÏÃ÷µÄÑ§Éú. * One quarter of the country is reckoned as unproductive. È«¹úËÄ·ÖÖ®Ò»µÄÍÁµØÊÇ²»Ã«Ö®µØ.  2 (a) [Tf no passive ²»ÓÃì¶±»¶¯ÓïÌ¬] (infml ¿Ú) assume; think ¼Ù¶¨; Ïë; Ë¼ââ; ÈÏÎª: I reckon we'll go next week. ÎÒÏëÎÒÃÇÏÂĞÇÆÚÈ¥. * The news won't worry her, I reckon. ÎÒ¿´ÕâÏûÏ¢²»»áÊ¹Ëı²»°². * What do you reckon our chances are of arriving on time? ÄãÈÏÎªÎÒÃÇÓĞÃ»ÓĞ¿ÉÄÜ°´Ê±µ½´ï? (b) [Tf, Tt] calculate (time, price, age, etc) approximately; guess Ô¼ÂÔµØ¼ÆËã£¨Ê±¼ä¡¢ ¼Û¸ñ¡¢ ÄêÁäµÈ£©; ²ÂÏë: I reckon it will cost about 100. ÎÒ¹À¼Æ´óÔ¼Òª100Ó¢°÷. * We reckon to arrive in Delhi at noon. ÎÒÃÇ¹À¼ÆÕıÎçµÖ´ïµÂÀï.  3 [Tn] find out (the quantity, number, cost, etc) by using numbers; calculate Ëã³ö£¨ÊıÁ¿¡¢ ÊıÄ¿¡¢ ·ÑÓÃµÈ£©; ¼ÆËã: reckon the total volume of imports ¼ÆËã½ø¿ÚÉÌÆ·µÄ×ÜÁ¿ * Hire charges are reckoned from the date of delivery. ×â½ğÓÉ»õµ½Ö®ÈÕÆğ¼ÆËã.  4 (phr v) reckon sth in include sth in a calculation ½«Ä³ÊÂÎï¼ÆËãÔÚÄÚ: When you did your expenses, did you reckon in your taxi fares? Äã¼ÆËã·ÑÓÃÊ±, °Ñ¼Æ³Ì³µ·ÑËã½øÈ¥ÁËÂğ? reckon on sb/sth base one's plans on sb doing sth or on sth happening; rely on sb/sth Ö¸Íû»òÒÀÀµÄ³ÈË[Ä³ÊÂÎï]: Can I reckon on you to help? ÄãÄÜ°ïÖúÎÒÂğ? * We're reckoning on moving house in May. ÎÒÃÇÖ¸ÍûÖøÎåÔÂ·İ°á¼Ò. * You can't always reckon on (having) good weather. ×ÜÒÀÀµ£¨ÓĞ£©ºÃÌìÆøÊÇ¿¿²»×¡µÄ. reckon sth up find the sum or total of sth; count sth up ¼ÆËã; ½áËã: reckon up bills, accounts, costs, etc ½áËãÕÊµ¥¡¢ ÕÊÄ¿¡¢ ·ÑÓÃµÈ. reckon with sb/sth take sb/sth into account; consider sb/sth as important¿¼ÂÇµ½»òÖØÊÓÄ³ÈË[Ä³ÊÂÎï]: They had many difficulties to reckon with. ËûÃÇÓĞĞí¶àÀ§ÄÑÒª¿¼ÂÇ. * a force, fact,person to be reckoned with, ie that cannot be ignored²»¿ÉºöÊÓµÄÁ¦Á¿¡¢ ÊÂÊµ¡¢ ÈËÎï. reckon without sb/sth not take sb/sth into account; not consider sb/sth as important Î´¿¼ÂÇµ½»òÎ´ÖØÊÓÄ³ÈË[Ä³ÊÂÎï]: We wanted a quiet holiday, but we had reckoned without the children. ÎÒÃÇÔ­Ïë°²°²¾²¾²µØ¶È¼Ù, È´Ã»ÓĞ°Ñº¢×Ó¿¼ÂÇÔÚÄÚ.

/ 5rekEnE(r); `rZkEnL/ n device or table (of figures, etc) used as an aid to reckoning ¼ÆËãÆ÷; ¼ÆËã±í. Cf ²Î¿´ ready reckoner (ready).
reckoning

reflect
/ rI5flekt; rI`flZkt/ v  1 [esp passive ÓÈÓÃì¶±»¶¯ÓïÌ¬: Tn, Tn.pr] (a) ~ sb/sth (in sth) (of a mirror, etc) make a visible image of sb/sth £¨Ö¸¾µ×ÓµÈ£©Ó³³öÄ³ÈË[Ä³Îï]µÄÓ°Ïñ: trees reflected in a window/lake ´°ÉÏ[ºşÖĞ]Ó³³öµÄÊ÷Ó° * He looked at his face reflected in the mirror. ËûÕÕ¾µ×Ó¿´¿´Á³. (b) ~ sth (from sth) (of a surface) throw back (light, heat, sound) £¨Ö¸ÎïÌå±íÃæ£©·´Éä£¨¹â¡¢ ÈÈ¡¢ Éù£©: The heat reflected from the white sand formed a mirage. ÈÈÆø¾­°×É«µÄÉ³Ãæ·´ÉäĞÎ³ÉÁËò×¾°. * The moon shines with reflected light. ÔÂÇòÊÇ½å·´ÉäÑô¹â¶ø·¢¹âµÄ.  2 [Tn] (fig ±ÈÓ÷) show the nature of or express (sth); correspond to ±íÏÖ£¨Ä³ÊÂÎï£©µÄĞÔÖÊ; ±í´ï£¨Ä³ÊÂÎï£©; ·ûºÏ: Her sad looks reflected the nature of her thoughts. ËıÃæ´øÓÇÉËÏÔ³öĞÄÊÂÖØÖØ. * The literature of a period reflects its values and tastes. Ä³Ò»Ê±ÆÚµÄÎÄÑ§¿É·´Ó³³ö¸ÃÊ±ÆÚµÄ¼ÛÖµ¹ÛÄîºÍÉóÃÀ¹ÛÄî. * Increased sales were reflected in higher profits. ÏúÊÛÁ¿µÄÔö¼Ó´øÀ´ÁË¸ü´óµÄÀûÈó.  3 [I, Ipr, Tf, Tw no passive ²»ÓÃì¶±»¶¯ÓïÌ¬] ~ (on/upon sth) think deeply about, or remind oneself of, past events; consider ³ÁË¼»òË¼Òä£¨ÍùÊÂ£©; Ë¼¿¼: I need time to reflect (on your offer/on what you offered). ÎÒĞèÒªÊ±¼äÀ´¿¼ÂÇ£¨ÄãµÄ½¨Òé[ÄãÌá³öµÄ½¨Òé]£©. * She reflected that his argument was probably true. ËıĞÄÏëËûµÄÀíÓÉÒ²¿ÉÄÜ¶Ô. * How distant those times seemed now, he reflected. ËûÔÚÏëÄÇĞ©ÈÕ×ÓÏÖÔÚÒÑÏÔµÃ¶à÷áÒ£Ô¶.  4 (idm Ï°Óï) reflect (well, badly, etc) on sb/sth show or suggest that sb/sth is sound, unsound, etc ±íÃ÷»òÏÔ³öÄ³ÈË[Ä³ÊÂÎï]½¡È«¡¢ ²»½¡È«µÈ: This scandal will reflect badly on the Party as a whole. Õâ¼ş³óÎÅ¿ÉÒÔËµÃ÷Õâ¸öµ³ÔÚÕûÌåÉÏ²»½¡¿µ. reflect credit, discredit, etc on sb/sth (of actions, results, etc) bring honour, dishonour, etc to sb/sth £¨Ö¸ĞĞÎª¡¢ ½á¹ûµÈ£©¸øÄ³ÈË[Ä³ÊÂÎï]´øÀ´¹âÈÙ¡¢ ³ÜÈèµÈ: These excellent results reflect great credit on all our staff. reflection (Brit also reflexion) 
/ rI5flekFn; rI`flZkFEn/ n  1 (a) [U] reflecting or being reflected ·´Ó³; ·´Éä; ±íÏÖ; ³ÁË¼: heat transmitted by reflection ÓÉ·´Éä´«µ¼µÄÈÈ. (b) [C] thing reflected, esp an image in a mirror, still water, etc ±»·´Ó³»ò·´ÉäÖ®Îï; £¨ÓÈÖ¸¾µÖĞ¡¢ ¾²Ë®µÈÖĞµÄ£©Ó³Ïñ: see one's reflection in a polished table-top ÔÚ¹âÁÁµÄ×ÀÃæÉÏ¿´¼û×Ô¼ºµÄÓ³Ïñ * the reflection of the trees in the lake ºşÃæÓ³³öµÄÊ÷µÄµ¹Ó° * (fig ±ÈÓ÷) be a pale reflection of one's former self, eg after an illness Óë×Ô¼ºÒÔÇ°Ïà±È, ÃæÈİã¾ã²£¨Èç²¡áá£©.  2 [C] (fig ±ÈÓ÷) thing reflecting the nature of eg a person, task, etc ¿É·´Ó³ÈË¡¢ ÈÎÎñµÈµÄ±¾ÖÊµÄÊÂÎï: Your clothes are a reflection of your personality.Ò»¸öÈËµÄÒÂÖø¿É·´Ó³³öÆä¸öĞÔ.  3 (a) [U] thought or memory of past events; consideration ³ÁË¼; »ØÒä; Ë¼¿¼: lost in reflection ÏİÈë³ÁË¼ÖĞ * act without sufficient reflection Î´¾­ÉîË¼¼´²ÉÈ¡ĞĞ¶¯ * A moment's reflection will show you are wrong. Ö»ÒªÂÔ¼Ó¿¼ÂÇ¾Í¿É¿´³öÄã´íÁË. (b) [C] ~ (on sth) (often pl ³£×÷¸´Êı) (spoken or written expression of an) idea arising from this ¾­³ÁË¼¶ø²úÉúµÄÏë·¨£¨±í´ï³öµÄÓïÑÔ»òÎÄ×Ö£©: idle reflections on the past »ØÒäÍùÊÂµÄåÚÏë * publish one's reflections on sexism ·¢±í¶ÔĞÔ±ğÆçÊÓµÄ¿´·¨.  4 (idm Ï°Óï) be a (bad/poor/adverse) reflection on sb/sth harm the good reputation of sb/sth; imply blame or criticism of sb/sth Ëğº¦Ä³ÈË[Ä³ÊÂÎï]µÄÃûÉù; °µº¬ÔğÄÑ»òÅúÆÀ: Your remarks are a reflection on me/my character. ÄãµÄ»°ÊÇ¶ÔÎÒ[ÎÒµÄÈË¸ñ]µÄÎÛÈè. * This mess is a (poor) reflection on her competence. ÕâÖÖ»ìÂÒÇé¿öËµÃ÷ËıÄÑµ±´ËÈÎ. on reflection after reconsidering (sth) ÔÙ¾­¿¼ÂÇ: On further reflection, I saw that she might be right, after all. ÎÒÔÙÒ»¿¼ÂÇ, ·´µ¹¾õµÃ¿ÉÄÜ»¹ÊÇËı¶Ô. * She decided, on reflection, to accept the offer. ËıÖØĞÂ¿¼ÂÇáá, ¾ö¶¨½ÓÊÜÄÇ¸ö½¨Òé.
reflective
/ rI5flektIv; rI`flZktIv/ adj  1 (of a person, mood, etc) thoughtful £¨Ö¸ÈË¡¢ ĞÄÇéµÈ£©Ë¼¿¼µÄ, ³ÁË¼µÄ: in a reflective frame of mind ÔÚ³ÁË¼ÖĞ.  2 (of a surface, etc) reflecting (esp light) £¨Ö¸ÎïÌå±íÃæµÈ£©·´ÉäµÄ, ·´Ó³µÄ; £¨ÓÈÖ¸£©·´¹âµÄ: reflective number plates, eg on cars ·´¹âµÄºÅÂëÅÆ£¨ÈçÆû³µÉÏµÄ£©.

reflex
/ 5ri:fleks; `riflZks/ n (also `reflex action) involuntary action (eg sneezing or shivering) made instinctively in response to a stimulus ·´Éä×÷ÓÃ£¨ÊÜ´Ì¼¤ááµÄ±¾ÄÜ·´Ó¦, Èç´òÅçÌç»ò·¢¶¶£©: Sorry I hit you; it was a pure reflex. ¶Ô²»ÆğÎÒ×²ÖøÄãÁË; ÕâÍêÈ«ÊÇÎŞÒâµÄ. * have quick, slow, normal, etc reflexes ²úÉúÑ¸ËÙµÄ¡¢ »ºÂıµÄ¡¢ Õı³£µÄ...·´Éä¶¯×÷ * test/control one's reflexes ²âÑé[¿ØÖÆ]×Ô¼ºµÄ·´Éä¶¯×÷ * [attrib ×÷¶¨Óï] a reflex movement, response, etc, ie one arising from a reflex ·´ÉäÔË¶¯¡¢ ·´ÉäĞÔ·´Ó¦.
reflex angle 
angle of more than 180 ÓÅ½Ç£¨´óì¶ 180 µÄ½Ç£©.
reflex camera 
camera in which the object or scene to be photographed is reflected by a mirror, and focused on a large viewfinder for adjustment up to the moment of exposure ·´ÉäÊ½ÕÕÏà»ú.
reflexion
(Brit) = reflection.
reflexive
/ rI5fleksIv; rI`flZksIv/ n, adj (grammar) (word or form) showing that the action of the verb is performed on its subject ·´ÉíµÄ£¨´Ê»òĞÎÊ½£©£¨±íÊ¾¶¯´ÊµÄ¶¯×÷¼°ì¶Ê©¶¯Õß£©: a reflexive verb, pronoun, eg as in `He `cut himself.' ·´Éí¶¯´Ê¡¢ ´ú´Ê£¨Èç He cut himself£©.
reflexive
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨: The reflexive verb is usually stressed. For emphasis, the syllable -self/-selves of the reflexive pronoun may be stressed. ·´Éí¶¯´ÊÍ¨³£ĞëÖØ¶Á. Îª¼ÓÇ¿ÓïÆø, ·´Éí´ú´ÊÖĞµÄ -self/-selves Õâ¸öÒô½Ú¿ÉÒÔÖØ¶Á.

relation
/ rI5leIFn; rI`leFEn/ n  1 [U] ~ (between sth and sth); ~ (to sth) way in which one person or thing is related to another; similarity, contrast or connection between people, things or events £¨ÈË»òÊÂÎïÓëËûÕßµÄ£©ÁªÏµ, ¹ØÁª, ¹ØÏµ: the relation between rainfall and crop production ½µÓêÁ¿Óë×÷Îï²úÁ¿Ö®¼äµÄ¹ØÏµ * The cost of this project bears/has/shows no relation to the results, ie It does not justify them. ´ËÏîÄ¿µÄ·ÑÓÃÓëÆä³É¹û²»Ïà³Æ.  2 (a) [C] person who is related to another; relative Ç×Æİ; Ç×Êô: a close/near/distant relation of mine ÎÒµÄ½üÇ×[½Ï½üµÄÇ×Æİ/Ô¶Ç×] * a relation by marriage/law ÒöÇ×. (b) [U] family connection; kinship Ç×Æİ¹ØÏµ; Ç×Êô¹ØÏµ: Is he any relation (to you)? Ëû£¨¸úÄã£©ÊÇÇ×ÆİÂğ? * He's no relation (to me). Ëû£¨¸úÎÒ£©²»ÊÇÇ×Æİ. * What relation are you (to each other)? ie How are you related? ÄãÃÇ£¨±Ë´ËÖ®¼ä£©ÊÇÊ²÷áÇ×Êô¹ØÏµ?  3 relations [pl] ~s (between sb/sth and sb/sth); ~s (with sb/sth) links or contacts between people, groups, countries, etc; dealings £¨ÈË¡¢ ÍÅÌå¡¢ ¹ú¼ÒµÈÖ®¼äµÄ£©¹ØÏµ, ÁªÏµ; ½»Íù: diplomatic, international, business relations Íâ½»¡¢ ¹ú¼Ê¡¢ ÒµÎñ¹ØÏµ * the friendly relations (existing) between our countries ÎÒÃÇ¹ú¼ÒÖ®¼ä£¨´æÔÚµÄ£©ÓÑºÃ¹ØÏµ * Relations are rather strained (ie difficult or awkward) at present. Ä¿Ç°¹ØÏµÓĞĞ©½ôÕÅ. * break off (all) relations with one's family Óë¼ÒÍ¥¶Ï¾øÁË£¨Ò»ÇĞ£©ÁªÏµ.  4 (idm Ï°Óï) have (sexual) relations (with sb) have intercourse (with sb) Óë£¨Ä³ÈË£©·¢Éú£¨ĞÔ£©¹ØÏµ; Óë£¨Ä³ÈË£©ĞÔ½». in/with relation to sb/sth (fml ÎÄ) concerning sb/sth; with reference to sb/sth ÓëÄ³ÈË[Ä³ÊÂÎï]ÓĞ¹Ø; Éæ¼°Ä³ÈË[Ä³ÊÂÎï]. a poor relation => poor.
relationship 
n  1 ~ (between A and B); ~ (of A to/with B) state of being connected ¹ØÏµ; ¹ØÁª: the close relationship between industry and trade/of industry to trade ¹¤ÒµÓëÃ³Ò×¼äµÄÃÜÇĞ¹ØÏµ.  2 (a) ~ (between A and B); ~ (of A to B) state of being related by birth or marriage ÑªÔµ¹ØÏµ; ÒöÇ×¹ØÏµ: a father-son relationship¸¸×Ó¹ØÏµ. (b) ~ (between A and B); ~ (of A with B)emotional or sexual liaison ¸ĞÇéµÄ»òĞÔµÄ¹ØÏµ: have a relationship with sb ÓëÄ³ÈËÓĞÇé * Their affair did not develop into a lasting relationship. ËûÃÇµÄêÓÃÁ½»ÍùÎ´ÄÜ·¢Õ¹³ÉÎª³Ö¾ÃµÄ¹ØÏµ.  3 ~ (between A and B); ~ (of A with B) links or contacts; dealings ¹ØÏµ; ÁªÏµ; ½»Íù: a purely business relationship ´¿ÒµÎñ¹ØÏµ * The author had a good working relationship with his editor. ¸Ã×÷ÕßÓë±à¼­Ö®¼ä¹¤×÷¹ØÏµºÜÈÚÇ¢.
relation
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨: Compare relation, relationsand relationship. ÊÔ±È½Ïrelation¡¢ relations¡¢ relationshipÕâÈı¸ö´Ê. Relationship has the widest use, covering many of the meanings of relation and relations. *relationshipÓÃ·¨×î¹ã, °üÀ¨ÁËrelationºÍrelationsµÄĞí¶àº¬Òå.  1 Relation and relationshipcan be used of family connections *relationºÍrelationship¿ÉÓÃÒÔ±íÊ¾Ç×Êô¹ØÏµ: A relation of mine is coming to stay. ÎÒÓĞ¸öÇ×ÆİÒªÀ´´ËÔİ×¡. *  `What's your relationship to her?' `She's my cousin.' £àÄã¸úËıÊÇÊ²÷áÇ×Æİ?£§£àËıÊÇÎÒµÄ±íÃÃ.£§  2 Relationship can indicate a strong emotional association *relationship¿ÉÒÔÖ¸Ç¿ÁÒµÄ¸ĞÇéÁªÏµ: Their relationship has lasted many years. ËûÃÇµÄ¸ĞÇéÒÑÓĞºÜ¶àÄêÁË.  3 When speaking about less personal associations or friendships, relations or relationship is used Èô²»²àÖØ¸öÈË¹ØÏµ»òÓÑÒêÊ±, ¿ÉÓÃrelations»òrelationship: Relations with the USSR are improving. ÓëËÕÁªµÄ¹ØÏµÕıÔÚ¸ÄÉÆ. *  Britain has a unique relationship with the USA. Ó¢¹úÓëÃÀ¹úÖ®¼äµÄ¹ØÏµºÜÌØÊâ.  4 Relation and relationship can indicate a similarity or correspondence between things *relationºÍrelationship¿ÉÒÔ±íÊ¾ÊÂÎïÖ®¼äµÄÏàËÆ´¦»òÒ»ÖÂĞÔ: ÿ?ISome people say that there's no relation/relationship between violence on television and crimes of violence. relative
/ 5relEtIv; `rZlEtIv/ adj  1 ~ (to sth) considered in relation or proportion to sb/sth else; comparative £¨ÓëËûÈË[ËûÊÂÎï]£©Ïà¶ÔµÄ, ³É±ÈÀıµÄ, ±È½ÏµÄ: the relative merits of the two plans, candidates, cars Á½ÖÖ·½°¸¡¢ Á½¸öºòÑ¡ÈË¡¢ Á½Á¾Æû³µÔÚÏà±ÈÖ®ÏÂÏÔÊ¾³öµÄ³¤´¦ * Supply is relative to demand. ¹©Ó¦ÒªÓëĞèÇó±£³ÖÒ»¶¨±ÈÀı. * They are living in relative comfort, ie compared with other people or with themselves at an earlier time. relay
/ 5ri:leI; `rile/ n  1 fresh set of people or animals taking the place of others who have finished a period of work ½Ó°àµÄÈËÔ±»ò¶¯Îï: Rescuers worked in relays to save the trapped miners. ¾ÈÔ®ÈËÔ±ÂÖ°à¹¤×÷ÒÔÓª¾ÈÓöÄÑµÄ¿ó¹¤. * A new relay of horses was harnessed to the cart.ÓÃ×÷ÂÖ»»µÄÂí¶¼ÒÑÌ×µ½ÁËÄÇÁ¾Âí³µÉÏ. / rI5li:f; rI`lif/ n  1 (a) [U] method of carving ormoulding in which a design stands out from a flat surface¸¡µñ£¨·¨£©: in high/low relief, ie with the background cut out deeply/shallowly Éî[Ç³]¸¡µñ. report

rest
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨: When speaking about who or what remains from an original total, we use the rest or (more formal) the remainder ±íÊ¾ÔÚÔ­ÓĞ×ÜÌåÖĞÊ£ÏÂµÄÈË»òÊÂÎï, ¿ÉÓÃthe rest, ÔÚ½Ï×¯ÖØ³¡ºÏ¿ÉÓÃthe remainder: Some boys stay on after school; the rest/remainder (of them) go home. ·ÅÑ§áá×ÜÓĞĞ©ÄĞº¢×Ó²»×ß, ÆäÓàµÄÈË»Ø¼Ò. * The rest/remainder of the time was spent swimming. Ê£ÏÂµÄÊ±¼äÓÃÀ´ÓÎÓ¾. If something has been partly used or destroyed, we use remains or remnants. ÈôÄ³ÎïµÄÒ»²¿·ÖÒÑÓÃµô»ò»Ùµô, ÆäÊ£Óà»ò²Ğ´æ²¿·Ö¿ÉÓÃ remains»òremnants±íÊ¾. Of food left-overs is often used ÈôÎªÊ³Îï, Ôò¶àÓÃleft-overs: The remains/remnants/left-overs of the meal (ie the bits of food left uneaten) were fed to the dog. Ê£·¹Î¹¹·ÁË. Remains is also used of old buildings or dead bodies *remains»¹¿ÉÖ¸¹Å¾É½¨ÖşÎï»òÊ¬Ìå: the remains of an old castle ¹Å±¤µÄ·ÏĞæ *  human remains ÈËµÄÒÅÌå. A relic is a historical object and reminder of the past. *relicÖ¸ÀúÊ·ÒÅÎï¡¢ ÒÅ¼£ÒÔ¼°¼ÍÄîÎïÆ·. A residue is what is left after a process, especially a chemical one, has taken place. *residueÖ¸Ä³Ò»¹ı³Ì£¨ÓÈÖ¸»¯Ñ§·´Ó¦£©µÄ²ĞÓàÎï. There is a green residue in the bottom of the test tube. ÊÔ¹Üµ×²¿ÓĞÂÌÉ«µÄ³Áµí. In a mathematical calculation the remainder (in arithmetic) or the balance (in accounting) is the amount left after subtraction or division. ÔÚÊıÑ§¼ÆËãÖĞremainderÖ¸£¨ËãÊõÖĞµÄ£©²îÊı»òÓàÊı, balanceÖ¸£¨»á¼ÆÑ§ÖĞµÄ£©Óà¶î»ò²î¶î.

restrain

road
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨: In a town, street is the most general word for a road lined with buildings ÔÚ³ÇÕò, streetÊÇÖ¸µÀÂ·Ê±ÓÃµÃ×î¹ãµÄ´Ê, ÆäÁ½²àÓĞ½¨ÖşÎï: a street-map of London Â×¶Ø½ÖµÀÍ¼. In British English street is not used for roads outside towns but streets in towns may have the word Road in their names ÔÚÓ¢Ê½Ó¢ÓïÖĞ, street²»ÓÃÒÔÖ¸³ÇÕòÍâµÄµÀÂ·, ¶ø RoadÒ»´ÊÈ´¿ÉÓÃì¶³ÇÕò½ÖµÀµÄÃû³ÆÖĞ: Edgware Road °£ÆæÎ¤¶ûÂ·. An alley or lane is a narrow street between buildings. *alleyºÍlane¾ùÖ¸Ğ¡½Ö»òĞ¡Ïï. An avenueis usually a wide street of houses, often in the suburbs and lined with trees. *avenueÍ¨³£Ö¸Á½ÅÔÓĞ·¿×ÓµÄ¿íÀ«½ÖµÀ, ³£Ö¸½¼ÇøµÄÁÖÒñµÀ. (In US cities avenues often run at right angles to streets. ÔÚÃÀ¹ú³ÇÊĞÖĞ, avenueÓëstreetµÄ×ßÏò³£ÓĞ×İºáÖ®·Ö.) Roads (US highways) connect towns and villages *road£¨ÃÀ¹úÓÃhighway£©Ö¸Á¬½Ó³ÇÏçµÄ¹«Â·: a road-map of Ireland°®¶ûÀ¼¹«Â·½»Í¨Í¼. Motorways (US freeways/expressways) are built for long-distance traffic toavoid towns. *motorway£¨ÃÀ¹úÓÃfreeway/expressway£©Ö¸±Ü¿ª³ÇÕòµÄ³¤¾àÀë¸ßËÙ¹«Â·. A lane is a narrow country road which winds between fields, connecting villages. *laneÒàÖ¸½¼ÍâµÄÏÁÕ­Ğ¡Â·, òêÑÑ´©¹ıÌï¼ä, Á¬½Ó¸÷¸ö´åÂä. Highway is seldom used in British English except in certain official phrases *highwayÒ» ´ÊÔÚÓ¢Ê½Ó¢ÓïÖĞºÜÉÙÊ¹ÓÃ, ³ı·ÇÓÃì¶Ä³Ğ©¹Ù·½ÓÃÓïÖĞ: the Highway Code ¹«Â··¨¹æ. Road, Street, Lane and Avenue are the most common words used in street names and are often abbreviated in addresses to Rd, St, La, Ave. *Road¡¢ Street¡¢ Lane¡¢ AvenueÊÇÓÃì¶½ÖµÀÃû³ÆÖĞ×î³£ÓÃµÄ´Ê, ÊéĞ´µØÖ·Ê±³£ËõĞ´ÎªRd¡¢ St¡¢ La¡¢ Ave.

round

round

round
/ raUnd; raJnd/ v [Tn]  1 make (sth) into the shape of a circle, a ball, an oval, etc Ê¹£¨Ä³Îï£©³ÉÔ²ĞÎ¡¢ ÇòĞÎ¡¢ ÂÑĞÎµÈ: round the lips, eg when making the sound / u:; u/ °Ñ×ì´½´é³ÉÔ²ĞÎ£¨Èç·¢/ u:; u/ÒôÊ±£© * stones rounded by the action of water ÓÉì¶Ë®µÄ³åË¢¶ø±äÔ²µÄÊ¯¿é.  2 go round (sth) »·ÈÆ£¨Ä³Îï£©¶øĞĞ; ÈÆ¹ı£¨Ä³Îï£©: We rounded the corner at high speed. run through sth

(e) perform, act or rehearse sth ±íÑİ; °çÑİ; ÅÅÁ·: Could we run through Act 3 again, please? Çë´ó¼Ò°ÑµÚ3Ä»ÔÙÅÅÁ·Ò»±éºÃÂğ? (f) use up or spend (money) carelessly or wastefully »Ó»ô£¨½ğÇ®£©: She ran through a lot of money in her first term at university. ËıÉÏ´óÑ§µÚÒ»¸öÑ§ÆÚ¾Í»¨ÁËºÜ¶àÇ®. run sth through play (part of a film or tape) by passing it through a machine ²¥·Å£¨µçÓ°»òÂ¼Òô´øÆ¬¶Î£©: Could we run that sequence through again? ÔÛÃÇÔÙ°ÑÄÇÒ»¶ÎÖØ·ÅÒ»±éºÃÂğ?
run to sth 
(no passive ²»ÓÃì¶±»¶¯ÓïÌ¬) (a) extend to or reach (the specified amount or size) ´ïµ½£¨Ä³Ò»Êı¶î»ò¹æÄ££©: The book runs to 800 pages. ¸ÃÊé³¤´ï800Ò³. * Her latest novel has already run to three impressions. Ëı×î½ü³ö°æµÄÒ»²¿Ğ¡ËµÒÑ¾­Ó¡ĞĞÈı´ÎÁË. (b) (of a person) have enough money for sth; (of money) be enough for sth £¨Ö¸ÈË£©ÓĞ¹»×÷Ä³ÊÂÎïÓÃµÄÇ®; £¨Ö¸Ç®£©×ã¹»Ä³ÊÂÎïÖ®ÓÃ: We can't/Our funds won't run to a holiday abroad this year. ½ñÄêÎÒÃÇÃ»ÓĞÇ®[ÎÒÃÇµÄÇ®²»¹»]È¥¹úÍâ¶È¼Ù.
run up

run
NOTE ON USAGE : Compare run, trot, jog, gallop, sprint and race. ÊÔ±È½Ïrun¡¢ trot¡¢ jog¡¢ gallop¡¢ sprint¡¢ raceÿ?WÕâ¼¸¸ö´Ê. When describing movement that is faster than walking, run is the most general verb. ÃèÊö±ÈĞĞ×ß¿ìµÄ¶¯×÷, ×î³£ÓÃµÄ¶¯´ÊÊÇrun. People usually run in a race or when they are in a hurry Í¨³£runÓÃì¶ÈüÅÜ»òÓĞ¼±ÊÂµÄ³¡ºÏ: I was late for the train so I had to run. ÎÒÒª¸Ï²»ÉÏ»ğ³µÁË, ËùÒÔµÃÅÜÖøÈ¥. We generally jog for physical exercise, running steadily and not very fast. *jogÒ»°ãÓÃì¶½¡ÉíÔË¶¯, ÅÜµÃÎÈµ«²»Ì«¿ì. Trot and gallop are mainly used of horses. *trotºÍgallopÖ÷ÒªÖ¸ÂíÅÜ. When people trot, they run quite quickly with short steps ÈôÒÔtrotÖ¸ÈË, ÔòÒâÎªĞ¡²½¿ìÅÜ: The girls spent the afternoon trotting up and down the beach. ¹ÃÄïÃÇÒ»ÏÂÎç¶¼ÔÚº£Ì²ÉÏÇá¿ìµØÅÜÀ´ÅÜÈ¥. Informally, trot can mean simply to `go' ÔÚ¿ÚÓïÖĞ, trot¿ÉÖ±½ÓµØ±íÊ¾goÖ®Òâ: I'll just trot round to the shops for some bread. ÎÒ¾Íµ½¸½½üÉÌµêÈ¥ÂòĞ©Ãæ°ü. Gallop is to run fast *gallopÖ¸¿ìÅÜ: He came galloping up the road. ËûÑØÂ··É¿ìÅÜÀ´. Race suggests a need to run very fast, not always in competition *raceÖ¸ÓĞ¿ìËÙÅÜµÄ±ØÒª, µ«²»Ò»¶¨×ÜÊÇÖ¸±ÈÈü: She raced to the window to stop the child jumping out. ËıÒ»¸ö¼ı²½ÅÜµ½´°Ç°, ÖÆÖ¹ÄÇº¢×ÓÍùÍâÌø. Sprint is to run as fast as possible, usually over a short distance *sprintÖ¸¾¡Á¦¿ìÅÜ, Í¨³£¾àÀë½Ï¶Ì: You'll have to sprint if you want to catch the train. ÄãÒªÏë¸ÏÉÏ»ğ³µ, ¾ÍµÃ¿ìÅÜ¼¸²½.

running

rare
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨: A thing or an event may be rare when it is found or occurs infrequently. ºÜÉÙ¼ûµ½µÄ¶«Î÷»òºÜÉÙ·¢ÉúµÄÏÖÏó, ¿ÉÓÃrareÒ»´ÊÀ´±í´ï. Something, usually a thing in daily use, is scarce when it is hard to get because it is in short supply ÓĞĞ©¶«Î÷, Í¨³£ÎªÈÕÓÃÆ·, ÒòØÑ·¦¶øÄÑÒÔµÃµ½, ¼´ÊÇscarce: Water is scarce in the desert. re-
pref (used widely with vs and related ns, adjs and advs ¿É×÷Ğí¶à¶¯´Ê¼°ÓÉ¶¯´ÊÅÉÉúµÄÃû´Ê¡¢ ĞÎÈİ´ÊºÍ¸±´ÊµÄÇ°×º) again ÔÙ; ÓÖ; ÖØĞÂ: reapply * redecoration * re-entered * reassuringly.
re-
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨: In many verbs beginning with re- the prefix is pronounced / rI-; rI-/ or / re-; rZ-/ and it may have lost its original meaning of `again' or `back' ÔÚÒÔ re- ¿ªÊ¼µÄĞí¶à¶¯´ÊÖĞ, Õâ¸öÇ°×º¶Á×÷ / rI-; rI-/ »ò / re-; rZ-/, ²¢ÓĞ¿ÉÄÜÒÑÊ§È¥Ô­À´µÄ£àÔÙ¡¢ ÓÖ£§»ò£à»Ø£§µÈÒâÒå: / rI-; rI-/ recall, repair; / re-; rZ-/ represent. Other verbs have had re- added to them with the meaning of `again' and it is pronounced / ri:-; ri-/ ÁíÓĞÒ»Ğ©¶¯´Ê¼Ó re- ±íÊ¾£àÔÙ¡¢ ÓÖ£§Ö®Òâ, ¶Á×÷ /ri:-; ri/: reopen; recreate. There are a few verbs which fit into both groups and a hyphenmay be used to show the distinction »¹ÓĞÒ»Ğ©¶¯´ÊÊÊºÏì¶ÉÏÊöÁ½ÖÖÇé¿ö, ¿ÉÓÃÁ¬½ÓºÅ±íÊ¾ÕâÖÖÇø±ğ: recount / rI5kaUnt; rI`kaJnt/ = `tell a story', re-count / 9ri:5kaUnt;9ri`kaJnt/ = `count again'; recover / rI5kQvE(r); rI`kQvL/ = `get back' or `become well again', re-cover / 9ri:5kQvE(r);9ri`kQvL/ = `supply with a new cover'.

reach 
n  1 [sing] extent to which a hand, etc can be stretched out ÉìÊÖµÈ¿É´ïµ½µÄ¾àÀë: a boxer with a long reach ³öÈ­¾àÀëÔ¶µÄÈ­»÷ÊÖ.  2 [C usu pl Í¨³£×÷¸´Êı] continuous extent of a river between two bends or of a canal between two locks £¨ºÓÁ÷Á½ÍäÇú´¦»òÔËºÓÁ½´¬Õ¢Ö®¼äµÄ£©ºÓ¶Î: the upper/lower reaches of the Thames Ì©ÎîÊ¿ºÓµÄÉÏ[ÏÂ]ÓÎ.  3 (idm Ï°Óï) beyond/out of/within (one's) `reach (a) outside or inside the distance that a hand, etc can be stretched out ÊÖ²»ÄÜ¼°[ÉìÊÖ¿É¼°]: have a dictionary within (arm's) reach °Ñ´Êµä·ÅÔÚ£¨ÉìÊÖ£©¹»µÃÖøµÄµØ·½ * The shelf is so high it is well out of/beyond my reach. ¼Ü×ÓÌ«¸ß, ÎÒ¸ù±¾¹»²»Öø. * Keep those medicines out of reach of the children/out of the children's reach. °ÑÄÇĞ©Ò©·ÅÔÚº¢×Ó¹»²»ÖøµÄµØ·½. / rI5Akt; rI`Akt/ v  1 [I, Ipr] ~ (to sb/sth) behave differently or change as a result of sth; respond ×÷³ö·´Ó¦; »ØÓ¦: Pinch me and I will react. ËıÊÜËûÎêÈèÖ®áá¾Í²»ÔÙÀí²ÇËûÁË.  2 [I, Ipr] ~ (against sb/sth) respond to sb/sth with hostility, resistance, etc ·´¶Ô; ·´¿¹; ·´¶¯: react strongly against tax increases Ç¿ÁÒ·´¶ÔÔöË° * Will the people ever react against this dictator? ÓĞ³¯Ò»ÈÕÈËÃñ»áÆğÀ´·´¿¹Õâ¸ö¶À²ÃÕßÂğ?  3 (chemistry »¯) (a) [I, Ipr, Ip] ~ with sth; ~ (together) (of substances) undergo changes by coming into contact with sth £¨Ö¸ÎïÖÊ£©Æğ»¯Ñ§·´Ó¦: Iron reacts with water and air to produce rust. reading age

/ 5rIElIzEm; `rIEl9IzEm/ n [U]  1 attitudes and behaviour based on the acceptance of facts and the rejection of sentiment and illusion ÏÖÊµÖ÷ÒåµÄÌ¬¶ÈºÍĞĞÎª.  2 (in art and literature) portrayal of familiar things as they really are without idealizing them £¨ÎÄÒÕµÄ£©ÏÖÊµÖ÷Òå, Ğ´ÊµÖ÷Òå. really

reason
/ 5ri:zn; `rizn/ n  1 [C, U] ~ (for sth/doing sth); ~ (to do sth); ~ (why.../that...) reason
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨: A cause (of something) is what makes something happen *causeÖ¸ÊÂÎï·¢ÉúµÄÔ­Òò: The police are investigating the cause of the explosion. ¾¯·½ÕıÔÚµ÷²é±¬Õ¨µÄÔ­Òò. *  The causes of the First World War. µÚÒ»´ÎÊÀ½ç´óÕ½µÄÆğÒò. Reason (for something) has a wider use. *reasonÒ»´ÊÓÃ·¨½Ï¹ã. It can be the explanation that people give for why something is done ¿ÉÓÃÒÔ½âÊÍ×öÄ³ÊÂµÄÔ­Òò»òÀíÓÉ: What was the reason for his resignation? ? *  She didn't give any reasons for leaving. ËıÎ´×öÈÎºÎ½âÊÍ¾Í×ßÁË. Reason, justification and cause (for something) can indicate that the explanation is acceptable to people in general, or reasonable *reason¡¢ justification¡¢ causeÈı´Ê¾ùÖ¸ÓÃÒÔ½âÊÍµÄÀíÓÉÊÇÒ»°ãÈË¶¼¿ÉÒÔ½ÓÊÜµÄ, »òÔ»reasonable: The police had no reason to suspect him/no justification for suspecting him/no cause for suspicion (ie They didn't suspect him or shouldn't have suspected him). ¾¯·½ÊÇÃ»ÓĞÀíÓÉ»³ÒÉËûµÄ£¨¼´: ¾¯·½Î´»³ÒÉËû»ò²»¸Ã»³ÒÉËû£©. ÿ?BGround is the formal, especially legal, justification for an action. *groundÊÇÓÃì¶½Ï×¯ÖØ³¡ºÏµÄÁíÒ»Í¬Òå´Ê, ÓÈÓÃì¶·¨ÂÉÎÄ¼şÖĞ. It is commonly used in the plural ´Ë´Ê³£ÓÃ×÷¸´Êı: Boredom is not a ground for divorce. ÈÕ¾ÃÉúÑá²»ÄÜ³ÉÎªÀë»éµÄÀíÓÉ. *  I left my job on medical grounds. ÎÒÓÉì¶½¡¿µÔ­Òò¶ø´ÇÈ¥ÁË¹¤×÷. A motive for doing something is a feeling or desire within people which makes them act *motiveÖ¸Ïë×öÄ³ÊÂµÄ¸Ğ¾õ»òÔ¸Íû: He claimed that his motive for stealing was hunger. ËûËµËûÒòÎª¶ö²ÅÈ¥Íµ¶«Î÷. *  The crime seemed to have been committed without (a) motive. ÕâÒ»×ï°¸ËÆºõ²¢ÎŞ×÷°¸¶¯»ú.
reason
/ 5ri:zn; `rizn/ v  1 (a) [I] use one's power to think, understand, form opinions, etc Ë¼¿¼; Àí½â; ÍÆÀí: man's ability to reason ÈËµÄË¼¿¼ÄÜÁ¦. (b) [Tf no passive ²»ÓÃì¶±»¶¯ÓïÌ¬] conclude or state as a step in this process ÍÆÂÛ; ÍÆ¶Ï: He reasoned that if we started at dawn, we would be there by noon. ËûÍÆ¶Ï, ÎÒÃÇÒªÊÇÀèÃ÷³ö·¢, ÖĞÎç¾ÍÄÜµ½.  2 (phr v) reason sb into/out of sth persuade sb by argument to do/not to do sth ÒÔÀíËµ·şÄ³ÈË×ö[²»×ö]Ä³ÊÂ: reason sb out of his fears È°ËµÄ³ÈËÏû³ı¿Ö¾å * She was reasoned into a sensible course of action. recently
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨: Recently, not long ago, lately indicate that the action spoken about took place in the recent past. *recently¡¢ not long ago¡¢ lately¾ùÖ¸×î½ü·¢Éú¹ıµÄÊÂ.  1 Recently has the widest use, in positive and negative statements and questions, with the past tense and the present perfect tense *recentlyÓÃ·¨×î¹ã, ¿ÉÓÃì¶¿Ï¶¨Ê½³ÂÊö¾ä¡¢ ·ñ¶¨Ê½³ÂÊö¾ä¼°ÒÉÎÊ¾äÖĞ, Óë¹ıÈ¥Ê±Ì¬ºÍÏÖÔÚÍê³ÉÊ±Ì¬Á¬ÓÃ: Did she have a party recently? Ëı×î½ü¾Ù°ì¹ı¾Û»áÂğ? *  They've recently bought a new car. ËûÃÇ²»¾ÃÇ°ÂòÁËÒ»Á¾ĞÂÆû³µ.  2 Not long ago is only used in positive statements with the verb in the past tense *not long ago½öÓÃì¶¿Ï¶¨Ê½³ÂÊö¾äÖĞ, Óë¶¯´Ê¹ıÈ¥Ê±Ì¬Á¬ÓÃ: They arrived in Britain not long ago/recently. ËûÃÇ²»¾ÃÒÔÇ°[×î½ü]µ½´ïÓ¢¹ú. *  It's not long ago that they arrived in Britain. ËûÃÇÊÇ²»¾ÃÒÔÇ°µ½´ïÓ¢¹úµÄ.  3 Lately is used in questions and negative statements. *latelyÓÃì¶ÒÉÎÊ¾äºÍ·ñ¶¨Ê½³ÂÊö¾äÖĞ. In positive statements it is used generally with only, much and a lot. ÈôÓÃì¶¿Ï¶¨Ê½³ÂÊö¾äÖĞ, Í¨³£Óëonly¡¢ much¡¢ a lotÁ¬ÓÃ. The verb must be in the present perfect tense¶¯´Ê±ØĞëÓÃÏÖÔÚÍê³ÉÊ±Ì¬: Have you seen him lately/recently? Äã½üÀ´[×î½ü]¼û¹ıËûÂğ? *  They haven't written lately/recently. ËûÃÇ½üÀ´[×î½ü]Ã»ÓĞĞ´ĞÅ. *  She's only lately/recently begun working here. ËıÖ»ÊÇ½üÀ´[×î½ü]²Å¿ªÊ¼ÔÚÕâÀï¹¤×÷µÄ. *  I've seen a lot of her lately/recently. ÎÒ½üÀ´[×î½ü]³£¼ûµ½Ëı.

ËıÊÇ°àÉÏ×î´ÏÃ÷µÄÑ§Éú. * One quarter of the country is reckoned as unproductive. È«¹úËÄ·ÖÖ®Ò»µÄÍÁµØÊÇ²»Ã«Ö®µØ.  2 (a) [Tf no passive ²»ÓÃì¶±»¶¯ÓïÌ¬] (infml ¿Ú) assume; think ¼Ù¶¨; Ïë; Ë¼ââ; ÈÏÎª: I reckon we'll go next week. ÎÒÏëÎÒÃÇÏÂĞÇÆÚÈ¥. * The news won't worry her, I reckon. ËûÃÇÎŞ·¨µ÷ºÍ±Ë´ËµÄ·ÖÆç.  2 [Tn, Tn.pr] ~ sth (with sth) make (aims, statements, ideas, etc) agree when they seem to conflict Ê¹£¨ËÆÓĞ·ÖÆçµÄÄ¿±ê¡¢ Ëµ·¨¡¢ Òâ¼ûµÈ£©Ò»ÖÂ, ºÍĞ³: reconcile the evidence with the facts Ê¹Ö¤¾İ·ûºÏÊÂÊµ * Can eating fish be reconciled with vegetarianism? ³ÔÓãÓëËØÊ³Ö÷ÒåÓĞÃ¬¶ÜÂğ?  3 [Tn.pr] ~ sb/oneself to sth (cause sb to) accept reluctantly sth unwelcome, unpleasant, etc £¨Ê¹Ä³ÈË£©ÎŞ¿ÉÄÎºÎµØ½ÓÊÜÄ³ÊÂÎï: The high salary reconciled me to living abroad. / rI5flekt; rI`flZkt/ v  1 [esp passive ÓÈÓÃì¶±»¶¯ÓïÌ¬: Tn, Tn.pr] (a) ~ sb/sth (in sth) (of a mirror, etc) make a visible image of sb/sth £¨Ö¸¾µ×ÓµÈ£©Ó³³öÄ³ÈË[Ä³Îï]µÄÓ°Ïñ: trees reflected in a window/lake ´°ÉÏ[ºşÖĞ]Ó³³öµÄÊ÷Ó° * He looked at his face reflected in the mirror. ÈÈÆø¾­°×É«µÄÉ³Ãæ·´ÉäĞÎ³ÉÁËò×¾°. * The moon shines with reflected light. ÔÂÇòÊÇ½å·´ÉäÑô¹â¶ø·¢¹âµÄ.  2 [Tn] (fig ±ÈÓ÷) show the nature of or express (sth); correspond to ±íÏÖ£¨Ä³ÊÂÎï£©µÄĞÔÖÊ; ±í´ï£¨Ä³ÊÂÎï£©; ·ûºÏ: Her sad looks reflected the nature of her thoughts. ËıÃæ´øÓÇÉËÏÔ³öĞÄÊÂÖØÖØ. * The literature of a period reflects its values and tastes. Ä³Ò»Ê±ÆÚµÄÎÄÑ§¿É·´Ó³³ö¸ÃÊ±ÆÚµÄ¼ÛÖµ¹ÛÄîºÍÉóÃÀ¹ÛÄî. * Increased sales were reflected in higher profits. ÏúÊÛÁ¿µÄÔö¼Ó´øÀ´ÁË¸ü´óµÄÀûÈó.  3 [I, Ipr, Tf, Tw no passive ²»ÓÃì¶±»¶¯ÓïÌ¬] ~ (on/upon sth) think deeply about, or remind oneself of, past events; consider ³ÁË¼»òË¼Òä£¨ÍùÊÂ£©; Ë¼¿¼: I need time to reflect (on your offer/on what you offered). reflexive
/ rI5fleksIv; rI`flZksIv/ n, adj (grammar) (word or form) showing that the action of the verb is performed on its subject ·´ÉíµÄ£¨´Ê»òĞÎÊ½£©£¨±íÊ¾¶¯´ÊµÄ¶¯×÷¼°ì¶Ê©¶¯Õß£©: a reflexive verb, pronoun, eg as in `He `cut himself.' ·´Éí¶¯´Ê¡¢ ´ú´Ê£¨Èç He cut himself£©.
reflexive
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨: The reflexive verb is usually stressed. For emphasis, the syllable -self/-selves of the reflexive pronoun may be stressed. ·´Éí¶¯´ÊÍ¨³£ĞëÖØ¶Á. Îª¼ÓÇ¿ÓïÆø, ·´Éí´ú´ÊÖĞµÄ -self/-selves Õâ¸öÒô½Ú¿ÉÒÔÖØ¶Á.

register

relation
/ rI5leIFn; rI`leFEn/ n  1 [U] ~ (between sth and sth); ~ (to sth) way in which one person or thing is related to another; similarity, contrast or connection between people, things or events £¨ÈË»òÊÂÎïÓëËûÕßµÄ£©ÁªÏµ, ¹ØÁª, ¹ØÏµ: the relation between rainfall and crop production ½µÓêÁ¿Óë×÷Îï²úÁ¿Ö®¼äµÄ¹ØÏµ * The cost of this project bears/has/shows no relation to the results, ie It does not justify them. ´ËÏîÄ¿µÄ·ÑÓÃÓëÆä³É¹û²»Ïà³Æ.  2 (a) [C] person who is related to another; relative Ç×Æİ; Ç×Êô: a close/near/distant relation of mine ÎÒµÄ½üÇ×[½Ï½üµÄÇ×Æİ/Ô¶Ç×] * a relation by marriage/law ÒöÇ×. (b) [U] family connection; kinship Ç×Æİ¹ØÏµ; Ç×Êô¹ØÏµ: Is he any relation (to you)? Ëû£¨¸úÄã£©ÊÇÇ×ÆİÂğ? * He's no relation (to me). Ëû£¨¸úÎÒ£©²»ÊÇÇ×Æİ. * What relation are you (to each other)? ie How are you related? ÄãÃÇ£¨±Ë´ËÖ®¼ä£©ÊÇÊ²÷áÇ×Êô¹ØÏµ?  3 relations [pl] ~s (between sb/sth and sb/sth); ~s (with sb/sth) links or contacts between people, groups, countries, etc; dealings £¨ÈË¡¢ ÍÅÌå¡¢ ¹ú¼ÒµÈÖ®¼äµÄ£©¹ØÏµ, ÁªÏµ; ½»Íù: diplomatic, international, business relations Íâ½»¡¢ ¹ú¼Ê¡¢ ÒµÎñ¹ØÏµ * the friendly relations (existing) between our countries ÎÒÃÇ¹ú¼ÒÖ®¼ä£¨´æÔÚµÄ£©ÓÑºÃ¹ØÏµ * Relations are rather strained (ie difficult or awkward) at present. Ä¿Ç°¹ØÏµÓĞĞ©½ôÕÅ. * break off (all) relations with one's family Óë¼ÒÍ¥¶Ï¾øÁË£¨Ò»ÇĞ£©ÁªÏµ.  4 (idm Ï°Óï) have (sexual) relations (with sb) have intercourse (with sb) Óë£¨Ä³ÈË£©·¢Éú£¨ĞÔ£©¹ØÏµ; Óë£¨Ä³ÈË£©ĞÔ½». in/with relation to sb/sth (fml ÎÄ) concerning sb/sth; with reference to sb/sth ÓëÄ³ÈË[Ä³ÊÂÎï]ÓĞ¹Ø; Éæ¼°Ä³ÈË[Ä³ÊÂÎï]. a poor relation => poor.
relationship 
n  1 ~ (between A and B); ~ (of A to/with B) state of being connected ¹ØÏµ; ¹ØÁª: the close relationship between industry and trade/of industry to trade ¹¤ÒµÓëÃ³Ò×¼äµÄÃÜÇĞ¹ØÏµ.  2 (a) ~ (between A and B); ~ (of A to B) state of being related by birth or marriage ÑªÔµ¹ØÏµ; ÒöÇ×¹ØÏµ: a father-son relationship¸¸×Ó¹ØÏµ. (b) ~ (between A and B); ~ (of A with B)emotional or sexual liaison ¸ĞÇéµÄ»òĞÔµÄ¹ØÏµ: have a relationship with sb ÓëÄ³ÈËÓĞÇé * Their affair did not develop into a lasting relationship. ËûÃÇµÄêÓÃÁ½»ÍùÎ´ÄÜ·¢Õ¹³ÉÎª³Ö¾ÃµÄ¹ØÏµ.  3 ~ (between A and B); ~ (of A with B) links or contacts; dealings ¹ØÏµ; ÁªÏµ; ½»Íù: a purely business relationship ´¿ÒµÎñ¹ØÏµ * The author had a good working relationship with his editor. ¸Ã×÷ÕßÓë±à¼­Ö®¼ä¹¤×÷¹ØÏµºÜÈÚÇ¢.
relation
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨: Compare relation, relationsand relationship. ÊÔ±È½Ïrelation¡¢ relations¡¢ relationshipÕâÈı¸ö´Ê. Relationship has the widest use, covering many of the meanings of relation and relations. *relationshipÓÃ·¨×î¹ã, °üÀ¨ÁËrelationºÍrelationsµÄĞí¶àº¬Òå.  1 Relation and relationshipcan be used of family connections *relationºÍrelationship¿ÉÓÃÒÔ±íÊ¾Ç×Êô¹ØÏµ: A relation of mine is coming to stay. ÎÒÓĞ¸öÇ×ÆİÒªÀ´´ËÔİ×¡. *  `What's your relationship to her?' `She's my cousin.' £àÄã¸úËıÊÇÊ²÷áÇ×Æİ?£§£àËıÊÇÎÒµÄ±íÃÃ.£§  2 Relationship can indicate a strong emotional association *relationship¿ÉÒÔÖ¸Ç¿ÁÒµÄ¸ĞÇéÁªÏµ: Their relationship has lasted many years. ËûÃÇµÄ¸ĞÇéÒÑÓĞºÜ¶àÄêÁË.  3 When speaking about less personal associations or friendships, relations or relationship is used Èô²»²àÖØ¸öÈË¹ØÏµ»òÓÑÒêÊ±, ¿ÉÓÃrelations»òrelationship: Relations with the USSR are improving. ÓëËÕÁªµÄ¹ØÏµÕıÔÚ¸ÄÉÆ. *  Britain has a unique relationship with the USA. Ó¢¹úÓëÃÀ¹úÖ®¼äµÄ¹ØÏµºÜÌØÊâ.  4 Relation and relationship can indicate a similarity or correspondence between things *relationºÍrelationship¿ÉÒÔ±íÊ¾ÊÂÎïÖ®¼äµÄÏàËÆ´¦»òÒ»ÖÂĞÔ: ÿ?ISome people say that there's no relation/relationship between violence on television and crimes of violence. ÓĞĞ©ÈËËµµçÊÓÖĞµÄ±©Á¦¾µÍ·ÓëÉú»îÖĞµÄ±©Á¦·¸×ï²¢ÎŞ¹ØÏµ.
relative
/ 5relEtIv; `rZlEtIv/ adj  1 ~ (to sth) considered in relation or proportion to sb/sth else; comparative £¨ÓëËûÈË[ËûÊÂÎï]£©Ïà¶ÔµÄ, ³É±ÈÀıµÄ, ±È½ÏµÄ: the relative merits of the two plans, candidates, cars Á½ÖÖ·½°¸¡¢ Á½¸öºòÑ¡ÈË¡¢ Á½Á¾Æû³µÔÚÏà±ÈÖ®ÏÂÏÔÊ¾³öµÄ³¤´¦ * Supply is relative to demand. ¹©Ó¦ÒªÓëĞèÇó±£³ÖÒ»¶¨±ÈÀı. * They are living in relative comfort, ie compared with other people or with themselves at an earlier time. relative 
n person who is related to another; relation Ç×Æİ; Ç×Êô: a close/near/distant relative of hers ËıµÄ½üÇ×[½Ï½üµÄÇ×Æİ/Ô¶Ç×].
relatively 
adv  1 in relation or proportion to sb/sth else; comparatively £¨ÓëËûÈË[ËûÊÂÎï]£©Ïà¶ÔµØ, ±È½ÏµØ: Considering the smallness of the car, it is relatively roomy inside. ±ğ¿´ÕâÁ¾Æû³µĞ¡, ÀïÃæ»¹±È½Ï¿í³¨. * Relatively speaking, this matter is unimportant. relativism
/ 5relEtIvIzEm; `rZlEtI9vIzEm/ n [U] belief that truth is not always and generally valid, but is limited by the nature of the human mind Ïà¶ÔÖ÷Òå£¨ÈÏÎªÕæÀí²¢·ÇÔÚÈÎºÎÊ±ºò¡¢ ÈÎºÎµØ·½¶¼Õ¾µÃ×¡½Å, ¶øÊÇÊÜµ½ÈËµÄÈÏÊ¶Ë®Æ½µÄ¾ÖÏŞ£©.
relativity
/ 9relE5tIvEtI; 9rZlE`tIvEtI/ n [U]  1 state of being relative(1) Ïà¶ÔĞÔ.  2 (physics Îï) Einstein's theory of the universe, which shows that all motion is relative and treats time as a fourth dimension related to space Ïà¶ÔÂÛ.

relay
/ 5ri:leI; `rile/ n  1 fresh set of people or animals taking the place of others who have finished a period of work ½Ó°àµÄÈËÔ±»ò¶¯Îï: Rescuers worked in relays to save the trapped miners. ¾ÈÔ®ÈËÔ±ÂÖ°à¹¤×÷ÒÔÓª¾ÈÓöÄÑµÄ¿ó¹¤. * A new relay of horses was harnessed to the cart.ÓÃ×÷ÂÖ»»µÄÂí¶¼ÒÑÌ×µ½ÁËÄÇÁ¾Âí³µÉÏ. Cf ²Î¿´ shift2 2.2 (also `relay race) race between teams in which each member runs, swims, etc part of the total distance, the second, etc member starting when the first, etc finishes £¨ÈüÅÜ¡¢ ÓÎÓ¾µÈµÄ£©½ÓÁ¦Èü: [attrib ×÷¶¨Óï] a relay team, runner, etc ½ÓÁ¦¶Ó¡¢ ÈüÅÜÔË¶¯Ô±µÈ.  3 (a) (radio ÎŞ) electronic device for receiving signals and transmitting them again with greater strength, thus increasing the distance over which they are carried ÖĞ¼ÌÉè±¸: [attrib×÷¶¨Óï] a relay station ÖĞ¼ÌÕ¾. (b) broadcast, programme or telegraph message sent out in this way ÎŞÏßµç×ª²¥; ×ª²¥µÄ½ÚÄ¿; ÎŞÏßµçÖĞ¼ÌÍ¨Ñ¶: a relay from Radio Hamburg ºº±¤¹ã²¥µçÌ¨µÄ×ª²¥.

relentless

relevant

remain
/ rI5meIn; rI`men/ v (usu not used in the continuous tenses Í¨³£²»ÓÃì¶½øĞĞÊ±Ì¬)  1 [I] be left or still present after other parts have been removed or used or dealt with Ê£ÏÂ; Ê£Óà; ÒÅÁô: After the fire, very little remained of my house. »ğÔÖ¹ıáá, º®ÉáËùÊ£ÎŞ¼¸. * If you take 3 from 8, 5 remains. 8¼õ3Ê£5. * The fact remains that she was lying. responsible
/ rI5spCnsEbl; rI`spBnsEbl/ adj  1 [pred ×÷±íÓï] ~ (for sb/sth); ~ (for doing sth) legally or morally obliged, eg to take care of sb/sth or to carry out a duty, and liable to be blamed if one fails £¨ÔÚ·¨ÂÉÉÏ»òµÀÒåÉÏ£©Ğë¸ºÔğÈÎ, ³Ğµ£ÔğÈÎ: All pilots are responsible for their passengers' safety. ·²ÊÇ·É»ú¼İÊ»Ô±¾ùÓ¦¶Ô³Ë¿ÍµÄ°²È«¸ºÔğ. * I am wholly/partly responsible for the confusion. ÄãÓ¦¸Ã¸öÈËÖ§¸¶ÕâĞ©ÕÊ.  2 [pred ×÷±íÓï] ~ to sb/sth having to account for one's actions to an authority or a superior ¶Ô×Ô¼ºµÄĞĞ¶¯ÏòÖ÷¹ÜÕß»òÉÏ¼¶³Ğµ£ÔğÈÎ: be directly/indirectly responsible to the PresidentÖ±½Ó[¼ä½Ó]Ïò×ÜÍ³¸ºÔğ.  3 [pred ×÷±íÓï] ~ (for sth) answerable for one's behaviour Ó¦¶Ô×Ô¼ºµÄĞĞÎª¸ºÔğ: A drunk man cannot be held/considered fully responsible for his actions. ×íºº²»ÄÜÎªÆäĞĞÎª¸ºÈ«²¿ÔğÈÎ.  4 (a) (of people) capable of being relied on; trustworthy £¨Ö¸ÈË£©¿É¿¿µÄ, ¿ÉĞÅÀµµÄ: behave like responsible citizens, adults, committee members ×öÓĞÔğÈÎĞÄµÄ¹«Ãñ¡¢ ³ÉÄêÈË¡¢ Î¯Ô± * She is very responsible for (ie considering that she is) a six-year-old. ¶Ôì¶ÁùËêµÄº¢×ÓÀ´Ëµ, ËıËãÊÇºÜ¿¿µÃ×¡µÄ. rest
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨: When speaking about who or what remains from an original total, we use the rest or (more formal) the remainder ±íÊ¾ÔÚÔ­ÓĞ×ÜÌåÖĞÊ£ÏÂµÄÈË»òÊÂÎï, ¿ÉÓÃthe rest, ÔÚ½Ï×¯ÖØ³¡ºÏ¿ÉÓÃthe remainder: Some boys stay on after school; the rest/remainder (of them) go home. ·ÅÑ§áá×ÜÓĞĞ©ÄĞº¢×Ó²»×ß, ÆäÓàµÄÈË»Ø¼Ò. * The rest/remainder of the time was spent swimming. Ê£ÏÂµÄÊ±¼äÓÃÀ´ÓÎÓ¾. If something has been partly used or destroyed, we use remains or remnants. ÈôÄ³ÎïµÄÒ»²¿·ÖÒÑÓÃµô»ò»Ùµô, ÆäÊ£Óà»ò²Ğ´æ²¿·Ö¿ÉÓÃ remains»òremnants±íÊ¾. Of food left-overs is often used ÈôÎªÊ³Îï, Ôò¶àÓÃleft-overs: The remains/remnants/left-overs of the meal (ie the bits of food left uneaten) were fed to the dog. Ê£·¹Î¹¹·ÁË. Remains is also used of old buildings or dead bodies *remains»¹¿ÉÖ¸¹Å¾É½¨ÖşÎï»òÊ¬Ìå: the remains of an old castle ¹Å±¤µÄ·ÏĞæ *  human remains ÈËµÄÒÅÌå. A relic is a historical object and reminder of the past. *relicÖ¸ÀúÊ·ÒÅÎï¡¢ ÒÅ¼£ÒÔ¼°¼ÍÄîÎïÆ·. A residue is what is left after a process, especially a chemical one, has taken place. *residueÖ¸Ä³Ò»¹ı³Ì£¨ÓÈÖ¸»¯Ñ§·´Ó¦£©µÄ²ĞÓàÎï. There is a green residue in the bottom of the test tube. ÊÔ¹Üµ×²¿ÓĞÂÌÉ«µÄ³Áµí. In a mathematical calculation the remainder (in arithmetic) or the balance (in accounting) is the amount left after subtraction or division. ÔÚÊıÑ§¼ÆËãÖĞremainderÖ¸£¨ËãÊõÖĞµÄ£©²îÊı»òÓàÊı, balanceÖ¸£¨»á¼ÆÑ§ÖĞµÄ£©Óà¶î»ò²î¶î.

ring
/ rIN; rIN/ v (pt rang / rN; rAN/, pp rung / rQN; rQN/)1 [I] make a clear resonant sound, usu like that of a bell being struck ·¢³öÇåÎúÏìÁÁµÄÉùÒô£¨Í¨³£Ö¸ËÆÁåÉù£©: Will you answer the telephone if it rings? µç»°ÁåÉùÏìÊ±ÇëÄã½Óµç»°ºÃÂğ? * The metal door rang as it slammed shut. ½ğÊôÃÅÃÍÒ»¹ØÉÏÊ±·¢³ö¡¡¹âµÄÏìÉù. * The buzzer rang when the meal was ready. ·¹×öºÃÊ±·äÎØÆ÷·¢³ö¡¡×È¡¡×ÈµÄÏìÉù.  2 [Tn, Tn.pr] cause (a bell, etc) to sound Ê¹£¨ÖÓÁåµÈ£©·¢Éù: ring the fire alarm ÃùÏì»ğ¾¯¾¯±¨ * ring the bell for school assembly ÇÃÖÓÍ¨ÖªÈ«Ğ£¼¯ºÏ.  3 [La] produce a certain effect when heard ²úÉúÄ³ÖÖÉùÒôĞ§¹û; ÌıÆğÀ´: Her words rang hollow, ie What she said sounded insincere. / rIsk; rIsk/ n  1 [C, U] ~ (of sth/that...) (instance of the) possibility of meeting danger or suffering harm, loss, etc Î£ÏÕ; ·çÏÕ: Is there any risk of the bomb exploding? road
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨: In a town, street is the most general word for a road lined with buildings ÔÚ³ÇÕò, streetÊÇÖ¸µÀÂ·Ê±ÓÃµÃ×î¹ãµÄ´Ê, ÆäÁ½²àÓĞ½¨ÖşÎï: a street-map of London Â×¶Ø½ÖµÀÍ¼. In British English street is not used for roads outside towns but streets in towns may have the word Road in their names ÔÚÓ¢Ê½Ó¢ÓïÖĞ, street²»ÓÃÒÔÖ¸³ÇÕòÍâµÄµÀÂ·, ¶ø RoadÒ»´ÊÈ´¿ÉÓÃì¶³ÇÕò½ÖµÀµÄÃû³ÆÖĞ: Edgware Road °£ÆæÎ¤¶ûÂ·. An alley or lane is a narrow street between buildings. *alleyºÍlane¾ùÖ¸Ğ¡½Ö»òĞ¡Ïï. An avenueis usually a wide street of houses, often in the suburbs and lined with trees. *avenueÍ¨³£Ö¸Á½ÅÔÓĞ·¿×ÓµÄ¿íÀ«½ÖµÀ, ³£Ö¸½¼ÇøµÄÁÖÒñµÀ. (In US cities avenues often run at right angles to streets. ÔÚÃÀ¹ú³ÇÊĞÖĞ, avenueÓëstreetµÄ×ßÏò³£ÓĞ×İºáÖ®·Ö.) Roads (US highways) connect towns and villages *road£¨ÃÀ¹úÓÃhighway£©Ö¸Á¬½Ó³ÇÏçµÄ¹«Â·: a road-map of Ireland°®¶ûÀ¼¹«Â·½»Í¨Í¼. Motorways (US freeways/expressways) are built for long-distance traffic toavoid towns. *motorway£¨ÃÀ¹úÓÃfreeway/expressway£©Ö¸±Ü¿ª³ÇÕòµÄ³¤¾àÀë¸ßËÙ¹«Â·. A lane is a narrow country road which winds between fields, connecting villages. *laneÒàÖ¸½¼ÍâµÄÏÁÕ­Ğ¡Â·, òêÑÑ´©¹ıÌï¼ä, Á¬½Ó¸÷¸ö´åÂä. Highway is seldom used in British English except in certain official phrases *highwayÒ» ´ÊÔÚÓ¢Ê½Ó¢ÓïÖĞºÜÉÙÊ¹ÓÃ, ³ı·ÇÓÃì¶Ä³Ğ©¹Ù·½ÓÃÓïÖĞ: the Highway Code ¹«Â··¨¹æ. Road, Street, Lane and Avenue are the most common words used in street names and are often abbreviated in addresses to Rd, St, La, Ave. *Road¡¢ Street¡¢ Lane¡¢ AvenueÊÇÓÃì¶½ÖµÀÃû³ÆÖĞ×î³£ÓÃµÄ´Ê, ÊéĞ´µØÖ·Ê±³£ËõĞ´ÎªRd¡¢ St¡¢ La¡¢ Ave.

run out

(of a container or its contents) overflow £¨Ö¸ÈİÆ÷»òËùÊ¢Ö®Îï£©Òç³ö: The bath/The bath water is running over. run over with sth

run through sth

run
NOTE ON USAGE : Compare run, trot, jog, gallop, sprint and race. ÊÔ±È½Ïrun¡¢ trot¡¢ jog¡¢ gallop¡¢ sprint¡¢ raceÿ?WÕâ¼¸¸ö´Ê. When describing movement that is faster than walking, run is the most general verb. ÃèÊö±ÈĞĞ×ß¿ìµÄ¶¯×÷, ×î³£ÓÃµÄ¶¯´ÊÊÇrun. People usually run in a race or when they are in a hurry Í¨³£runÓÃì¶ÈüÅÜ»òÓĞ¼±ÊÂµÄ³¡ºÏ: I was late for the train so I had to run. ÎÒÒª¸Ï²»ÉÏ»ğ³µÁË, ËùÒÔµÃÅÜÖøÈ¥. We generally jog for physical exercise, running steadily and not very fast. *jogÒ»°ãÓÃì¶½¡ÉíÔË¶¯, ÅÜµÃÎÈµ«²»Ì«¿ì. Trot and gallop are mainly used of horses. *trotºÍgallopÖ÷ÒªÖ¸ÂíÅÜ. When people trot, they run quite quickly with short steps ÈôÒÔtrotÖ¸ÈË, ÔòÒâÎªĞ¡²½¿ìÅÜ: The girls spent the afternoon trotting up and down the beach. ¹ÃÄïÃÇÒ»ÏÂÎç¶¼ÔÚº£Ì²ÉÏÇá¿ìµØÅÜÀ´ÅÜÈ¥. Informally, trot can mean simply to `go' ÔÚ¿ÚÓïÖĞ, trot¿ÉÖ±½ÓµØ±íÊ¾goÖ®Òâ: I'll just trot round to the shops for some bread. ÎÒ¾Íµ½¸½½üÉÌµêÈ¥ÂòĞ©Ãæ°ü. Gallop is to run fast *gallopÖ¸¿ìÅÜ: He came galloping up the road. ËûÑØÂ··É¿ìÅÜÀ´. Race suggests a need to run very fast, not always in competition *raceÖ¸ÓĞ¿ìËÙÅÜµÄ±ØÒª, µ«²»Ò»¶¨×ÜÊÇÖ¸±ÈÈü: She raced to the window to stop the child jumping out. ËıÒ»¸ö¼ı²½ÅÜµ½´°Ç°, ÖÆÖ¹ÄÇº¢×ÓÍùÍâÌø. Sprint is to run as fast as possible, usually over a short distance *sprintÖ¸¾¡Á¦¿ìÅÜ, Í¨³£¾àÀë½Ï¶Ì: You'll have to sprint if you want to catch the train. ÄãÒªÏë¸ÏÉÏ»ğ³µ, ¾ÍµÃ¿ìÅÜ¼¸²½.
